sub_topic: Calculation of the number of electrons transferred in an electrochemical reaction
message_1: What is the number of electrons transferred when 0.2 moles of zinc ions (Zn2+) react with an excess of copper metal (Cu) to form solid copper ions (Cu2+) and zinc metal (Zn)? (Assume the reaction takes place in an aqueous solution with a standard electrode potential of 0.34 V at 25°C.)
message_2:
To determine the number of electrons transferred in this reaction, we first need to write the balanced redox equation for the reaction between zinc ions (Zn2+) and copper metal (Cu) to form solid copper ions (Cu2+) and zinc metal (Zn).

The half-reactions for this redox reaction are:

Oxidation half-reaction (Cu to Cu2+): Cu(s) → Cu2+(aq) + 2e⁻
Reduction half-reaction (Zn2+ to Zn): Zn2+(aq) + 2e⁻ → Zn(s)

Now, we can combine these half-reactions to form the balanced redox equation:

Cu(s) + Zn2+(aq) → Cu2+(aq) + Zn(s)

From the balanced redox equation, we can see that 2 moles of electrons are transferred for every mole of zinc ions reacting with copper metal. Since we have 0.2 moles of zinc ions reacting, we can calculate the number of electrons transferred as follows:

Number of electrons transferred = moles of Zn2+ × moles of electrons per mole of Zn2+
Number of electrons transferred = 0.2 moles × 2 moles of electrons
Number of electrons transferred = 0.4 moles of electrons

Therefore, 0.4 moles of electrons are transferred when 0.2 moles of zinc ions react with an excess of copper metal to form solid copper ions and zinc metal.
